Generation after generation was exempt from corvÃ©e labor, treated the same as Feng and Pei districts, with no advance levies. On the Xinyou day, an edict declared: 'In recent years, floods, droughts, and locust swarms have brought disaster. Grain prices have skyrocketed. (Meaning prices have surged dramatically. I reflect that the common people have no means to support themselves. I am deeply moved with compassion for them. Order that commanderies and kingdoms with surplus grain provide rations. (The Shuo Wen dictionary says: 'Bing means to grant grain.' Pronunciation: bÇ jÇn fÇn. (The Da Dai Li ritual text states: 'A man of sixty without a wife is called a widower; a woman of fifty without a husband is called a widow.' The Book of Rites states: 'A child without a father is called an orphan; an elder without children is called solitary.' The Er Ya dictionary explains: 'Du means hardship or distress.' The Cang Jie Pian dictionary states: '[ ], means illness.' The Han legal code is now lost. (Office is like regular/duty.

In summer, on the Bingzi day of the fourth month, the emperor visited Chang'an. He first paid respects at the Gao ancestral temple, then performed ceremonies at the eleven imperial mausoleums. ('Having affairs' means performing sacrifices. The Commentary of Zuo states: 'Performing affairs at the Grand Temple.' These were: Gaozu's Chang Mausoleum, Huidi's An Mausoleum, Wendi's Ba Mausoleum, Jingdi's Yang Mausoleum, Wudi's Mao Mausoleum, Zhaodi's Ping Mausoleum, Xuandi's Du Mausoleum, Yuandi's Wei Mausoleum, Chengdi's Yan Mausoleum, Aidi's Yi Mausoleum, and Pingdi's Kang Mausoleum.

On the Xinmao day of the sixth month, an edict declared: 'Establishing offices and appointing officials is done for the sake of the people.' (The Guanzi says: 'Establishing offices and appointing officials is to uphold the ruler's laws.' Counties and kingdoms that are insufficient to establish chief officials may be merged. (Bing pronunciation: bÃ¬ zhÃ¨ng fÇn. Thereupon they memorialized to merge and abolish over four hundred counties, reducing official positions to one-tenth of what they had been.

Dai commandery governor Liu Xing attacked Lu Fang's general Jia Lan at Gao Liu and died in battle. (Gao Liu was a county belonging to Dai commandery; its old city is in today's Dingxiang county in Yun province.

On the Dingchou day of the tenth month in winter, an edict declared: 'My virtue is thin and unenlightened. Bandits and rebels cause harm. The strong bully the weak. The common people have lost their proper place.' As the Poetry says: 'The sun and moon announce ill fortune; do not follow their proper courses.' (Zheng Xuan's commentary on the Shi Xiao Ya says: "To announce ill fortune is to announce to the world the omens of ruin and extinction." "Xing" means the proper measure of the path. "Not use them" means they interfere with and violate each other. ("Jiu" means illness/pain. As the Shi says: "The worried heart is greatly pained." (In the first year of Emperor Wu's Jian Yuan reign, he began issuing edicts to recommend gentlemen who were worthy and good, upright and proper, who spoke straightforwardly and remonstrated extremely. (Emperor Xuan began allowing the assembled ministers to submit sealed memorials in order to understand the sentiments of those below.

On the Dingmao day of the eleventh month, an edict declared: "Officials and people who were confiscated to become slaves and maidservants during Wang Mang's time, not conforming to the old laws, shall all be exempted and become commoners."

On the Guiwei day, an edict declared: "Recently the armies have not been disbanded and expenditures are insufficient, therefore we implement a tax of one-tenth." (Meaning to take one part from ten parts as the tax. Mencius said: "The Xia levied tribute on fifty-acre plots, the Yin provided assistance on seventy-acre plots, the Zhou alternated on hundred-acre plotsâ€”their substance was all one-tenth." (Emperor Wu initially opened relations with the Western Regions and began establishing commandants to cultivate fields. (In the second year of Emperor Jing's reign, the field rent was set at thirty parts with one part tax; now following Emperor Jing, therefore called the "old system".

Wei Xiao sent his general Xing Xun to invade Fufeng. (Xing is the surname; Xun is the given name. The Han dynasty had a Xing You who served as chancellor of Zhao; see the Fengsu Tong.

æ˜¯æ­²ï¼Œåˆç½·éƒ¡åœ‹éƒ½å°‰å®˜ã€‚ å§‹é£åˆ—ä¾¯å°±åœ‹ã€‚ åŒˆå¥´é£ä½¿ä¾†ç»ï¼Œä½¿ä¸­éƒå°‡å ±å‘½ã€‚ ã€ˆæ¼¢å®˜å„€æ›°ï¼šã€Œä½¿åŒˆå¥´ä¸­éƒå°‡ï¼Œæ“ç¯€ï¼Œç§©æ¯”äºŒåƒçŸ³ã€‚ã€ åŒˆå¥´å‚³äº‘ï¼šã€Œä»¤ä¸­éƒå°‡éŸ“çµ±å ±å‘½ï¼Œè³‚éºé‡‘å¹£ã€‚ã€
This year, the offices of commandery and kingdom commandants were initially abolished. Began dispatching the marquises to their feudal territories. In the seventh year, spring, first month, day Bing Shen, an imperial decree ordered that officials in the capital, the Three Metropolitan Areas, the commanderies, and the kingdoms release prisoners not guilty of capital crimes, and not investigate their offenses. Convicts who had been seen [by the emperor] were released to become common people. Fugitives who had endured punishment were officially removed from the records with documents. (To endure is the name of a light punishment. The Former Book's Sound and Meaning says: "One year of punishment is penal labor; two years of punishment and above is called enduring." Endure is pronounced Nai Dai, going against the norm. Fugitives are those who committed endure crimes and fled while changing their names. Order officials to create documents recording their names and removing their crimes, fearing that they would flee and not return, thus losing the name registers.

Another imperial decree stated: "The world considers lavish burials virtuous and meager burials vulgar, leading the wealthy to extravagant excess and the poor to exhaust their wealth. (Dan means to exhaust. (Sudden refers to mourning and chaos. Those who practiced lavish burials all suffered grave robberies, and therefore only then realized their fault. Fault means evil.

On the Ding You day of the third month, an imperial decree stated: "Now the state has many armies with many elite and brave soldiers. We should temporarily abolish the light chariot troops, cavalry, materials officials, tower ship soldiers, and army temporary officials. (The Han Guan Yi says: "Gaozu ordered all commanderies and kingdoms under heaven to select those able to draw crossbows and who had material strength and martial fierceness, establishing them as light chariot troops, cavalry, materials officials, and tower ship troops. They constantly practiced and tested after the autumn equinox, each having fixed numbers. On level ground they used chariot cavalry, in mountain obstacles they used materials officials, in deep waters they used tower ships." Army temporary officials refers to officials provisionally placed within the army. Now we abolish all of them.

On the last day of the month (Gui Hai), there was a solar eclipse. The emperor avoided the main hall, rested the troops, and did not attend to affairs for five days. An imperial decree stated: "My virtue is thin and has caused this disaster; blame appears in the sun and moon. (Blame means to blame. It is pronounced Zhi Ge, going against the norm. The Commentary of Zuo says: "When a ruler governs without using the good, he himself takes blame from the disasters of sun and moon." Now I am just reflecting on my faults, hoping to dispel this blame. Order all officials to each repair their duties and responsibilities, respectfully follow the laws and regulations, and show favor to these primordial people. All officials shall each present sealed memorials, concealing nothing. Those who submit memorials must not refer to the sage."

Initially, after Ba and Shu were already pacified, Grand Commander Wu Han presented a memorial requesting to enfeoff the imperial sons, but permission was not granted. He repeatedly memorialized for consecutive years. In the third month, an imperial decree was issued ordering the various ministers to discuss it. Grand Minister of Works Rong, Marquis of Gushi Tong, Marquis of Jiaodong Fu, Marquis of Gaomi Yu, Grand Master of Ceremonies Deng and others memorialized and discussed, saying: "The ancients enfeoffed various lords to screen and protect the capital. (Fan means fence. Ping means shield. The Shi Da Ya says: "Great persons as fence, great states as shield." Mao Chang's annotation says: "One should use dukes, ministers, and various lords as fence and shield." The Gongyang Commentary says: "What is Jing? It means great. What is Shi? It means crowd. The Son of Heaven's residence must be spoken of with words of crowd and greatness." Therefore the Shi says: "Greatly open your residence, to be the auxiliary of the Zhou chamber." (This is from the Shi Lu Song. Yu means to reside. Zhou Cheng King enfeoffed his son Bo Qin at Lu. It speaks of greatly opening your residence to be the auxiliary of our Zhou family. Your Majesty's virtue spans heaven and earth. You have risen to restore the ancestral system, praised virtue and rewarded merit, and closely harmonized the nine clans. (Kong An Guo's annotation on the Shang Shu says: "The nine clans mean from great-grandfather up to great-grandson down." Now the imperial sons rely on heaven, able to wear clothes and hasten to bow. Your Majesty, respectful and modest, overcomes yielding. You suppress it and do not discuss it. The various ministers and common people are none not disappointed. It is suitable to follow the flourishing summer's auspicious time, determine titles and positions, to broaden the fence and auxiliary. (The Li Ji Yue Ling says: "The Son of Heaven in the first month of summer welcomes summer at the southern suburb, returns, then enfeoffs various lords, carries out ranks and issues salaries." The minister requests the Grand Minister of Works to present the carriage land maps. (The Guang Ya says: "Yu means to carry." It speaks of carrying those on the ground, all mapping and painting them. The Minister of Works manages land, therefore he is commanded to present it. The imperial decree said: "Permissible."

The great surnames of the commanderies and kingdoms and soldier leaders, group thieves everywhere together rose up, attacking and plundering in their places, harming and killing chief officials. The commanderies and counties pursued and attacked, but upon arrival they dispersed, and when they left they gathered and united again. The four provinces of Qing, Xu, You, and Ji were especially severe. In the tenth month of winter, messengers were sent down to the commanderies and kingdoms, allowing group thieves to mutually correct and pick out their own, (Pick means to send. It is pronounced Ta Di, going against the norm. Officials who though delaying and staying to avoid, intentionally releasing them, were all not questioned, but were allowed to take capturing and attacking as their achievement.) Their governors, guards, commandants, and county magistrates who sat within their boundaries with bandit thieves and did not capture them, moreover those who with fear and timidity abandoned cities and entrusted their guards, were all not taken as negative. (Entrust guard means to abandon what they guarded. It speaks of evaluating those who resided after. First means the head of all important matters. It speaks of evaluating those who resided first. Then they mutually pursued and captured, and the thieves together dispersed. Their chief leaders were transferred to other commanderies, assigned fields and given provisions, causing them to settle and establish livelihoods. From this, oxen and horses were let to pasture, and town gates were not closed.

This summer, in the capital a sweet spring gushed out. (The Shangshu Zhonghou says "when talented and righteous men are in office, then sweet springs come out." This year, they initially built the Bright Hall, Spirit Terrace, Bi Yong, and the North Suburban marked domain. (The Da Dai Li says: "The bright hall altogether has nine rooms. One room has four doors and eight windows: thirty-six doors, seventy-two windows. It is covered with thatch above, round above and square below. Red binds the doors, white binds the windows." The Li Diagram again says: "In Jianwu thirty-first year, they made the bright hall, round above and square below. Twelve halls follow the method of the day stems. Nine rooms follow the method of the nine provinces. Each room has eight windows: eight times nine is seventy-two, following the method of one age's king. Each room has twelve doors, following the method of yin and yang numbers." Hu Bo Shi says: "Ancient clear temples were covered with thatch. Now they are covered with tiles, but below they are matted with thatch, preserving the ancient system." The Han Official Ceremony says: "The bright hall has earth raised on four sides to make a moat, with a bridge above. There is no water in the middle of the moat. The bright hall is two li from the Level City gate. When the Son of Heaven exits, he goes from the Level City gate, first passes through the bright hall, then reaches the suburban sacrifice." It also says: "The Bi Yong is three hundred steps from the bright hall. When the imperial carriage arrives at the Bi Yong, it enters from the north gate. In the third month and ninth month, they all perform the archery ritual at the Middle Row township. The Bi Yong is surrounded by water on the outside, to control the viewers. Feudal lords call it the Pan Palace. East, west, and south have water, north has none, lowering the Son of Heaven." The Han Palace Pavilion Sparse says: "The spirit terrace is three zhang high, with twelve gates. The Son of Heaven calls it the spirit terrace, feudal lords call it the observation terrace." The Han Official Ceremony: "The north suburban altar is in the northwest corner of the city, one li from the city. It is made as a square altar with four steps, but has only the altar sacrifice house. Its drum and wind music, dancers, and imperial tents are all moved from the south suburban equipment. The earth spirit position faces south and is west upper. The High Empress Dowager is paired, facing west. All are on the altar. The geography many spirits follow and eat below the altar. South suburban sacrifices burn the calf, north suburban sacrifices bury the calf." Again exempt Jiyang and Nandong from this year's corvee labor. The Can Wolf Qiang invaded Wudu and defeated the commandery soldiers. Longxi Governor Liu Xu sent troops to save them, and together with Wudu commandery soldiers attacked the rebel Qiang, breaking them all.

Initially, the emperor had been at leisure from military affairs for a long time. He was weary of military matters, and moreover knew that all under heaven was tired and exhausted. He thought of peaceful rest for the shoulders. (The Zuo Zhuan says: "rest the shoulder at Jin." The Imperial Crown Prince once asked about matters of attack and battle. The emperor said: "Formerly Wei Ling Gong asked Chen, Confucius did not answer. This is not something you have reached." (The Lunyu: "Wei Ling Gong asked Chen of Confucius. He said: 'Zu dou matters I have once heard of; military campaigns matters I have not learned.'" He frequently led the dukes and ministers, lang officials, and generals to lecture and discuss the classics and governance, sleeping only when the night was half over. (Half is like half. The emperor said: "I myself enjoy this, and do not consider it tiring." Though his person aided great achievement, he was fearful and fearful as if not reaching it. Therefore he was able to be bright and careful with the governmental body, controlling the authority's outline, measuring time and gauging strength, raising matters that did not exceed. He retired the merit ministers and advanced the wen officials, stored away the bows and arrows and scattered the horses and oxen. Though the way did not equal the ancients, this was also the martial virtue of stopping spears.) (The Zuo Zhuan says: "Regarding wen, stopping the spear is wu."
